title: How to Make Quilt Templates

steps.headline: Transfer the pattern onto paper first.
steps.description: If you don't want to mangle your magazine getting the pattern out of it, then make a photocopy or trace it onto paper.

steps.headline: Cut out the paper pattern.
steps.description: It's a bit flimsy, and won't hold up to multiple tracings, so quilters will use a variety of methods to get around the problem.

steps.headline: Make a lot of photocopies of each pattern shape and cut them all out.
steps.description: When one wears out, just pick up a replacement from the pile.

steps.headline: Fabricate cardboard templates.
steps.description: Cut out the paper pattern, trace the paper pattern onto some pressed cardboard, then cut longer-lasting patterns out of the cardboard. Cereal boxes work well for this.—They are often the perfect weight to cut easily yet be durable. Also, the price is right.

steps.headline: Use thin sheets of plastic.
steps.description: The plastic might be cutting mats from the kitchen section of your local department store or, perhaps, the lid of a plastic container, say, a whipped topping container lid. Trace your pattern onto the plastic and carefully cut it out and... Voila! You have a sturdy, reusable template!

steps.headline: Create foundation piecing by photocopying your entire block pattern onto thin paper.
steps.description: Grease proof paper works well for this.

steps.headline: Bring together a variety of material.
steps.description: Use the paper templates to cut out cloth patterns from from the material, then stitch the material together carefully.

tyn: Permanent marker (for transferring pattern onto the cardboard or material)
Variety of materials (cut into desired shapes)
